##Diary of the siege of Wuhan | Day 6

Techread

Features, Lanxi, founder of zhulu.com  , focuses on in-depth observations and business reviews of Internet startups, new media, and subcultures.

The folk activity of opening windows and shouting "Go Wuhan" together and singing the national anthem together at the appointed time yesterday was really quite confusing.

It seems to me that the people of Wuhan are in a state of mild euphoria -- a kind of Androgyny -- a feature not uncommon in a society that has experienced collective memory.

The concept of collective memory, invented by Western psychologists, the proximity of the plague and the unprecedented blockade, inadvertently provided a utopian experience that would have been hard to reach in a lifetime, this led to the creation of a ritual to relieve stress.

In a sense, it's not that different from the ice bucket challenge, which was all the rage.

Academic theories suggest that collective memory is an inheritance of collectivism, like primitive humans dancing around a campfire, an act that doesn't make much sense in itself, but which all members must do in order to construct a tribal totem.

I don't know, the reality is still pretty raw, and after a few cheers in several neighborhoods, there was a call for an emergency shutdown -- as was the case in Florida.

The reason for the halt is also valid: upstairs and downstairs saliva droplets scattered with the wind, increasing the risk of infection.

I think this is also very ridiculous. If this probability should be taken into account, then the anti-epidemic advice of opening a window to ventilate should be deleted at all, because you don't know when you ventilate, is there a Gone with the River of spray from an upstairs apartment that just floats right up your nose.

Everyone's strings are too tight.

Another comment I can't help but make is that the document ends with the line, "tell the mayor to call off this citywide behavior! "! "

If you think it's a bad idea, don't do it. Why does the mayor have to make the next announcement? What happens after the notification? We got eyes on every house?

In short, this fleeting episode, in fact, is not much harm, it has a funny side, there is a lovely side, as a means of building collective memory, eventually evolved into collective memory material, will surely find a place in time.

As Marcos Paulo Souza Ribeiro writes, "the threat of hardship and death... will force a more intense romantic culture... and the opening of a window to sing... may be Love in the Time of Cholera, but it's still romantic, no doubt.

On the other hand, the people of Wuhan probably also need the empathy of the people of the whole country. On the one hand, they are full of empathy, "one side is in difficulty, all sides are supporting" , and on the other hand, they regard the people of Wuhan as hostile, like a flood of animals, living in these two very different emotions, it is inevitable to feel split and aggrieved.

Yes, of course we can understand that as a suspect in an epidemic area running around, he will bring hidden dangers to his compatriots in other areas, but isn't it a little over the top to take pictures of people with long knives standing guard at the provincial border in case of a Wuhan invasion as a hard core, hilarious sketch?

Isn't there a more decent way to do this? I don't believe it.

Or Rather, I believe that the development of modern medicine and civilised institutions, has long since passed the choice between the village of Leprosy and the ship of fools, in a more mature, humane and flexible way, to solve problems that have been historically overwhelming.

Another person sent me a private message saying that I had reposted an article about an American Doomsday survival group building a sanctuary farm, in which they would often practice survival rules, such as if the world were going to collapse, there was a hungry mother with a young child outside the farm, and they had to make the hard decision to refuse.

I mean, the worst case scenario we're facing right now, isn't the blue-faced Zombie epidemic, or the wasteland after the nuclear war, right? It's understandable to be wary of the Wuhan People, but you don't have to treat all the people in Wuhan like thieves.

A little more human touch doesn't put your safety at risk.

This is my diary of the siege of Wuhan, day six.
